Description: Upper body sherd (mended from two fragments) of South Ionian pottery cup, presumably with everted rim; interior: black areas top and bottom, reserved band between with single black line; exterior: reserved band above black area; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer suggests that the sherd belongs to a Type 9 South Ionian cup with everted rim. The lack of rim and other diagonstic features makes it impossible to confirm the type to which the cup belongs. Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. This type evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18).
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 54, no. 18)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.262) (Phase 3)
